documents.title: Documents
documents.content: Citizens of many countries can enter South Korea visa-free for tourism for up to 90 days. A K-ETA (Korea Electronic Travel Authorization) is required for visa-free entry. Apply for your K-ETA online at least 72 hours before your departure. Your passport must be valid for at least 6 months upon entry. Ensure you have proof of onward or return travel. Always carry a form of identification, as it can be requested by officials.

culture.title: Culture
culture.content: South Korean culture is a dynamic blend of deep-rooted Confucian principles and ultra-modern trends. Respect for elders and social hierarchy are important. A slight bow is a common greeting, often accompanied by a handshake. When receiving or giving items, use both hands to show respect. Tipping is not a custom in South Korea and is not expected. Age is very important in social interactions; it's polite to ask someone's age to establish hierarchy.

safety.title: Safety
safety.content: South Korea is an incredibly safe country with very low crime rates. It's safe to walk around at night in most areas. Petty crime like pickpocketing is rare, but always be aware of your belongings. The emergency number is 112 for police and 119 for fire/ambulance. Be mindful of the border with North Korea and avoid unauthorized tours. Protests and demonstrations can occur; it's best to avoid them.

health.title: Health
health.content: Healthcare standards are very high. Tap water is safe, but most locals boil it or drink bottled water. Air quality can be poor at times (yellow dust). Travel insurance is highly recommended to cover the costs of medical treatment. Pharmacies are plentiful and well-stocked for common ailments. Check air quality levels on apps like AirVisual, especially in spring. Face masks are commonly used for both health and fashion reasons.

money.title: Money
money.content: The currency is the South Korean Won (KRW). Credit cards are accepted almost everywhere, even for small purchases. It's one of the most cashless societies. Carry a small amount of cash for traditional markets or street food vendors. A T-money card is essential for public transport and can also be used in convenience stores. ATMs with global card support are common, but look for a 'Global' sign. A mid-range budget would be around ₩70,000-₩100,000 per day.

connectivity.title: Connectivity
connectivity.content: South Korea boasts some of the world's fastest internet and an incredibly efficient, clean, and punctual public transport system. Free Wi-Fi is ubiquitous in cafes, subways, and public spaces. Renting a Wi-Fi egg (portable hotspot) or getting a tourist SIM is easy and affordable. Use apps like Naver Maps or Kakao Maps for navigation, as Google Maps has limited functionality. The KTX high-speed train connects the country efficiently.

adaptation.title: Adaptation
adaptation.content: Embrace the 'ppalli-ppalli' (hurry, hurry) culture, which reflects the fast-paced nature of life. Koreans are generally very friendly and helpful to foreigners. Learning some basic Hangul (the Korean alphabet) is surprisingly easy and very useful. Don't be shy to ask for help; people will often go out of their way to assist you. Korean food can be spicy; '안 맵게 해주세요' (an maep-ge hae-ju-se-yo) means 'Please make it not spicy'. Be prepared for a vibrant nightlife and a 24/7 convenience store culture.
